[[Image:Samir Kassir Poster reduced 60percent.jpgâ|right|thumbnail|175px|This poster commemorates the assassination of Samir Kassir. The poster reads as follows: Martyr of the [[Cedar Revolution|Independence Uprising]]; Democratic Left.]]
 
'''Samir Kassir''' (Ø³ÙÙØ± ÙØµÙØ± in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]) ([[May 5]] [[1960]] – [[June 2]] [[2005]]) was a professor of history at [[l'UniversitÃ© Saint-Joseph|Saint-Joseph University]] and [[journalist]].<ref>[http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2004/704/bo1.htm al-Ahram] 19 - 25 August 2004 Issue No. 704 ''The not so sick man of Europe'' By Rasha Salti</ref> Born to a [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] father and a [[Syrian people|Syrian]] mother.<ref name="SKnet">[http://www.samirkassir.net/ Samir Kassir.net]</ref> Kassir received his degree in philosophy and political philosophy in 1984, in 1990, Kassir earned his PhD in Modern History also from the University of Sorbonne.<ref name="SKnet"/> He held both Lebanese and French nationality. A prominent left-wing activist, he was a strong advocate of freedom for the Palestinians, democracy in Lebanon and [[Syria]] and a vocal critic of the [[Syrian occupation of Lebanon|Syrian presence in Lebanon]]. He was assassinated on [[2 June]] [[2005]] and his murderers remain unknown. A French investigation is currently underway but its results have yet to be released. Kassir was a keen advocate of secular democracy in the Middle east.
'''Samir Kassir''' (Ø³ÙÙØ± ÙØµÙØ± in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]) ([[May 5]] [[1960]] – [[June 2]] [[2005]]) was a professor of history at [[l'UniversitÃ© Saint-Joseph|Saint-Joseph University]] and [[journalist]].<ref>[http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2004/704/bo1.htm al-Ahram] 19 - 25 August 2004 Issue No. 704 ''The not so sick man of Europe'' By Rasha Salti</ref> Born to a [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] father and a [[Syrian people|Syrian]] mother.<ref name="SKnet">[http://www.samirkassir.net/ Samir Kassir.net]</ref> Kassir received his degree in philosophy and political philosophy in 1984, in 1990, Kassir earned his PhD in Modern History also from the University of Sorbonne.<ref name="SKnet"/> He held both Lebanese and French nationality. A prominent left-wing activist, he was a strong advocate of freedom for the Palestinians, democracy in Lebanon and [[Syria]] and a vocal critic of the [[Syrian occupation of Lebanon|Syrian presence in Lebanon]]. He was assassinated on [[2 June]] [[2005]] and his murderers remain unknown. A French investigation is currently underway but its results have yet to be released. Kassir was a keen advocate of secular democracy in the Middle east.
<blockquote>"What [Arab-American] reconciliation needs, if the United States were really willing to reach such reconciliation, is first [America's] revision of its understanding of Arab democracy, which has been restricted until now, to the American convention that mandates Arabs give up their pan-Arab ties... and the issues that steer their feelings most, on top of them the Palestinian issue,"<ref name="SKnet"/></blockquote>
<blockquote>"What [Arab-American] reconciliation needs, if the United States were really willing to reach such reconciliation, is first [America's] revision of its understanding of Arab democracy, which has been restricted until now, to the American convention that mandates Arabs give up their pan-Arab ties... and the issues that steer their feelings most, on top of them the Palestinian issue,"<ref name="SKnet"/></blockquote>
